title: 106_hr2309
content: The Act may be cited as the "Independent Medical Review Act of 1999" and includes special rules for group health plans. Section 503 of ERISA is amended to include special rules for group health plans, such as notification of appeal rights to utilization review agents and independent review organizations. Special rules for group health plans include notification of appeal rights to utilization review agents and independent review organizations, as well as procedures for appealing adverse determinations and obtaining immediate review for life-threatening conditions. Fair, de novo determination of medical necessity by the independent review is also outlined. The procedures for appealing adverse determinations and obtaining immediate review for life-threatening conditions include the right to immediate review by an independent review organization and fair, de novo determination of medical necessity without regard to the plan's definition. The procedures for appealing adverse determinations allow participants or beneficiaries to appeal orally or in writing to a utilization review agent. The agent must acknowledge receipt of the appeal within 5 working days and provide a list of required documents for the appeal. The utilization review agent must acknowledge receipt of an appeal within 5 working days and provide a list of required documents. If an oral appeal is made, a one-page appeal form will be sent to the appealing party. Appeal decisions will be made by a physician, but can be reviewed by a specialty provider if good cause is provided within 10 working days of denial. The appeal process includes decisions made by a physician, with the option for review by a specialty provider within 10 working days if good cause is provided. An expedited appeal procedure is in place for emergency care denials and life-threatening conditions. The expedited appeal procedure for emergency care denials and life-threatening conditions must be completed within one working day from receipt of all necessary information. The expedited appeal procedure for emergency care denials and life-threatening conditions must be completed within one working day from receipt of all necessary information. The utilization review agent must issue a response letter explaining the resolution of the appeal, including specific medical reasons and consultation details. Written notification of the resolution must be provided to the appealing party. The utilization review agent must provide a response letter detailing the resolution of the appeal, including specific medical reasons and consultation details. Written notification of the appeal determination must be sent to the appealing party within 30 days. If an appeal is denied, the participant can seek review from an independent organization. The independent review process includes specific elements. The independent review process, conducted by an independent review organization, ensures timely responses, confidentiality of medical records, and the independence of healthcare providers making review determinations. The independent review process guarantees confidentiality of medical records, independence of healthcare providers, and timely notification of review results to participants. Information must be provided to the independent review organization within 3 business days of receiving a request for review. The utilization review agent must provide relevant medical records, documents used in making the determination, and written notification to the independent review organization within 3 business days of receiving a request for review. The utilization review agent must provide medical records, documents, written notification, information submitted for appeal, and a list of relevant healthcare providers to the independent review organization within 3 business days. The independent review organization must make a determination within 15 days of receiving necessary information for the appeal, or within 20 days of receiving the appeal. A list of relevant healthcare providers must be provided to support the appeal. The independent review organization must make a determination within specific timeframes for non-life-threatening and life-threatening conditions. The independent review organization must make a determination within specific timeframes for life-threatening conditions, certified by the Secretary. The independent review organization must be certified by the Secretary and submit an annual application with specific information, including details on stockholders. The application to the Secretary must include details such as stockholders owning more than 5%, affiliated organizations, bond holders exceeding $100,000, and biographical information of directors, officers, and executives. The application to the Secretary must include details such as stockholders owning more than 5%, affiliated organizations, bond holders exceeding $100,000, and biographical information of directors, officers, and executives, along with any relationships they have with health insurance providers, health maintenance organizations, utilization review agents, or nonprofit health organizations. The application to the Secretary must include details such as ownership stakes, affiliations, bond holdings, and biographical information of key personnel, including any relationships with entities involved in health insurance, health maintenance, utilization review, or nonprofit health organizations. Additionally, the application should specify the anticipated revenue percentage from reviews conducted under this subsection. The application to the Secretary must include ownership details, affiliations, and biographical information of key personnel. It should also specify the anticipated revenue percentage from reviews conducted under this subsection, along with the expertise of health care professionals and procedures used by the independent review organization. The independent review determination is binding on the plan. The independent review organization's determination is final and binding on the plan, and may only be vacated or modified by a court under specific circumstances. An independence requirement is also mandated for the independent review process. The independent review organization's decision can only be changed by a court under specific circumstances. The organization must be independent and not owned or controlled by a payor. They are not liable for damages resulting from their determination. The term 'adverse determination' refers to a decision by a group health plan or utilization review agent that certain health care services are not medically necessary. 'Health care provider' includes individuals licensed to deliver health care services and entities engaged in such delivery. The term 'life-threatening condition' refers to a disease or medical condition where death or serious bodily injury is likely without interruption. It includes individuals and entities in a State required to be licensed or certified to deliver health care services. The term 'payor' includes insurers, preferred provider organizations, self-insurance plans, and entities providing health benefits. The term 'utilization review agent' refers to an entity that conducts utilization review for employers, payors, or administrators. A 'working day' is defined as a weekday excluding legal holidays.
